snippet: Only about 20 tunnels of 250 that once played a central role in the economy of Rafah are still operating — the worst situation smugglers can remember.

byline.contributor: Majd Al Waheidi contributed reporting from Rafah, and Kareem Fahim from Cairo.
byline.original: By DIAA HADID and WISSAM NASSAR

abstract: Rafah Journal; smugglers in Palestinian city of Rafah see end to their illegal trade after Egyptian forces flood tunnels in border area; only 20 of 250 tunnels are operational, diminishing Rafah's economy and raising concerns floods will ruin farmland and wash away building foundations; latest effort to destroy tunnels is part of crackdown by Egyptian defense minister Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, who maintains guns and militants flow through underground paths, compromising Egypt’s security.
lead_paragraph: Only about 20 tunnels of 250 that once played a central role in the economy of Rafah are still operating — the worst situation smugglers can remember.

headline.print_headline: Smugglers Fear Gaza Tunnel Flooding Will Kill Their Trade
headline.main: As Egypt Floods Gaza Tunnels, Smugglers Fear an End to Their Trade
